questions.question: Question 1: Which of these tests is used in case of a nominal data?
questions.explanation:
862 
Sold by @itachibot Chi-square test deals with nominal/ non-parametric data (qualitative). Nominal data is one with a name and does not have a numerical value. Ex blood group, gender, 
religion Student's t test, ANOVA, and paired t test are used for parametric data (quantitative).

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests?

options.a: ANOVA is an example of a non parametric test
options.b: It is used for skewed distributions
options.c: It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
options.d: It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.explanation:
Non-parametric tests are tests that do not assume that the data is normally distributed. Thus, they 
are used for skewed (asymmetric) distributions {skewed either to the lesser side (left-sided 
skewed) or towards the greater side (right-sided skewed)}. The chi-square test is an example of a non-parametric test that is used to test hypotheses in 
relation to nominal scale data or categorical data. ANOVA is an example of a parametric test.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of these terms is used for paired t tests?
questions.explanation:
Paired t tests are also called correlated pairs t test, paired samples t test, or dependent samples t 
test.

questions.question: Question 4: The test of significance done for two or more proportions:
questions.explanation:
Chi-Square(2) test is a test used for proportions and associations. It is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal 
scale data or categorical data.

questions.question: Question 5: A researcher can use the chi-square test in all of the following situations, except:

options.a: To test the hypothesis that drug A has the same potency as drug B
options.b: To calculate the degree of freedom of a 3 x 4 contingency table
options.c: To compare the mean corpuscular volume in normal subjects versus those suffering from
options.d: To compare the proportions of overweight boys and girls in a class

questions.explanation:
The Chi-square test is not used for comparing means for different groups as means can only be 
calculated for quantitative data. The Chi-square test is used for qualitative data. It can be used: • To test the null hypothesis • To compare proportions • To calculate the degree of freedom

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not true about the Chi-square test?

options.a: Tests the significance of difference between two proportions
options.b: Tells about the presence or absence of an association between two variables
options.c: Directly measures the strength of association
options.d: It is usually used for skewed data

questions.explanation:
863 
Sold by @itachibot A Chi-square test does not directly measure the strength of association. It merely tells about the 
presence or lack of association.

questions.question: Question 7: A Chi-square test would be most appropriate for testing which of the following hypotheses?

options.a: The mean AIPGE score of Chennai students is greater than Mumbai students
options.b: A smaller proportion of people who were immunized against chicken pox subsequently develop
options.c: The mean BP of indian, american and english hypertensive men taking ACE inhibitors is the
options.d: The mean cost of treating a patient with CAD by angioplasty is greater than the mean cost of

questions.explanation:
The Chi-square test is used to compare proportions or qualitative variables e.g., whether people 
developed zoster or not. Options A and D: Two independent groups are being compared with quantitative variables (exam 
scores and cost, respectively). Thus, an unpaired t test will be used. Option C: The blood pressure of 3 groups are being compared, thus making analysis of variance 
(ANOVA) the most appropriate method of testing significance.

questions.question:
Question 8: The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with 
one group being a control is: 857 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one 
group being a control is unpaired T test.

questions.question:
Question 9: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of the atorvastatin drug. She measures the initial 
cholesterol levels of 50 patients. After a month's treatment, she measures the cholesterol level 
again. Which of the following tests will she use to test the statistical significance of the change 
in the cholesterol level?
questions.explanation:
In this scenario, the variable (cholesterol level) is quantitative. Moreover, the comparison is being 
done before and after the treatment (dependent). Hence, a paired t test will be used.

questions.question:
Question 10: In a particular trial, the association of lung cancer with smoking is found to be 40% in one 
sample and 60% in another. What is the best test to compare the results?
questions.explanation: Chi-square tests are best used in comparing proportions and associations.

questions.question:
Question 11: A pediatrician carried out a study to assess the difference in growth velocities in boys and 
girls. The average height of a group of 20 boys aged 10 years was 140 ± 13 cm and for 20 girls 
of the same age was 135 ± 7 cm. To test the statistical significance of the difference in height, 
which test would she use?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, two independent groups are being compared with quantitative variables. 
Thus, a student t test or unpaired t-test is used.

questions.question:
Question 12: A clinical trial was done between two groups to measure their blood pressure after treatment. 
Which of the following tests would be appropriate to use?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, two groups are being compared independent of each other. 
Hence, students t test/ unpaired t test should be used. 864 
Sold by @itachibot T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, 
paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

questions.question: Question 13: Analysis of variance test is used in which scenario among the following?

options.a: Comparing proportions in more than 2 groups
options.b: Comparing means in more than 2 groups
options.c: Comparing means in same groups before and after intervention
options.d: Comparing means in less than or equal to 2 groups

questions.explanation:
Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 groups are compared for a quantitative 
difference (means).

questions.question:
Question 14: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 
30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the 
following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare 
qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures. Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the 
same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired. Option C: The standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of 
central tendency as mean. Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

questions.question:
Question 15: A study was conducted to compare the incidence of postpartum depression in mothers as 
compared to the sex of the child. For assessment, Edinburg Depression scaled score (EDSS) 
was used. The study was divided into mothers with male babies as one group to be compared 
with mothers with female babies. Which of the following statistical test will be used to 
determine the association? 859 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The Chi-square test is used to compare qualitative data and compares 2 groups with independent 
measures. The variables used here are yes/no signifying the presence/absence of postpartum 
depression. Hence it is the most appropriate test here. Option A: Student’s t-test is for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be 
used. Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the 
same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired. Option C: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is the most appropriate test for testing the statistical significance of 
the difference in heights of school children?
questions.explanation:
Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 variable groups are compared. In the scenario of comparing heights of school children, we would divide the school children into 
classes or grades or sections or by schools themselves, etc. This would involve comparing more 
than 2 groups and thus ANOVA is used. Remember if the question limits its comparison within 2 groups, for example, comparison 
between boys and girls in a class then we have to choose unpaired t test. 865 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: An investigator wants to study the association between maternal intake of iron supplements 
and the incidence of low birth weight. He collects relevant data from 100 pregnant women 
regarding the status of usage of iron supplements and the status of birth weight in their 
newborns. Which of the following tests will he use for his study?
questions.explanation:
Here, two qualitative variables are being evaluated. First, whether the child belongs to the low 
birth weight category or not (and not the actual weight of the child, which is a quantitative value). 
Second, whether or not the mother took iron supplements in the gestational period. Hence, 
the chi-square test is used as the test the significance of the association.

questions.question:
Question 18: In a study, two groups of newborns are checked for differences in their birth weights based on 
whether mothers received supplements or not. Which of the following would be most 
appropriate test of significance?
questions.explanation:
The unpaired t-test is used to test the difference between two groups of parametric variables or 
means when the samples are independent of each other. Here, birth weights (quantitative 
variable) of the two groups of newborns are being compared, which are independent of each 
other.

questions.question:
Question 19: A study was planned to find out the effect of iron supplementation during pregnancy on the 
birth weight of newborn children. Two groups, one with iron supplementation and the other 
without, were compared. Birth weights of newborns were recorded as means + SD. Which 
statistical test is appropriate for the comparison of birth weights between the two groups?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, we aim to compare only the birth weights of the two groups, which is 
a quantitative data, and thus an unpaired t test is most appropriate.

questions.question:
Question 20: While applying the Chi-square test to a contingency table of 4 rows and 4 columns, what 
would the degree of freedom be in this case?
questions.explanation:
In this scenario, df = (4 – 1) (4 – 1) = 9. In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the 
number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.question:
Question 21: In a Chi-square test for the following data, the degrees of freedom will be: 861 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In this scenario,contingency table has 3 rows and 4 columns. Hence, the degree of freedom, df = 
(3 – 1) (4 – 1) = 6. In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the 
number of rows and c is the number of columns. 866 
Sold by @itachibot Correlational and Predictive Techniques
